channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why flight disruptions could linger even after the government shutdown ends
item.description: Airlines and aviation regulators warned that flight disruptions are likely to continue even after the government reopens. Thousands of flights have been cancelled as air traffic restrictions ramp up.
item.content:encoded:
Airlines and aviation regulators warned that flight disruptions are likely to continue even after the government reopens. Thousands of flights have been cancelled as air traffic restrictions ramp up.

(Image credit: Chris O'Meara)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Supreme Court extends its order blocking full SNAP payments, with shutdown potentially near an end
item.description: The high court's decision keeps in place a chaotic situation. People who depend on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in some states have received their full monthly allocations, while others have received nothing.
item.content:encoded:
The high court's decision keeps in place a chaotic situation. People who depend on the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program in some states have received their full monthly allocations, while others have received nothing.

(Image credit: Stephanie Scarbrough)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Bros really are dominating podcasting
item.description: New research from the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative shows that both podcast hosts and their guests skew very heavily male – and white.
item.content:encoded: New research from the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative shows that both podcast hosts and their guests skew very heavily male – and white.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: This podcast says 'I've Had It' with Republicans – and Democrats who don't fight back
item.description: In a political podcast space dominated by men and displeasure with the Democratic Party, the two women behind the I've Had It show have seen viral success.
item.content:encoded:
In a political podcast space dominated by men and displeasure with the Democratic Party, the two women behind the I've Had It show have seen viral success.

(Image credit: Bryan Bedder)
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: Museums had a rough 2025: Report shows lower attendance, lost grants, less money
item.description: The American Alliance of Museums put out its annual industry snapshot and it's not great. Trump's targeting of museum programming had downstream effects and put a "chill on corporate philanthropy."
item.content:encoded:
The American Alliance of Museums put out its annual industry snapshot and it's not great. Trump's targeting of museum programming had downstream effects and put a "chill on corporate philanthropy."

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Andrew Limbong

item.title: 'What to Eat Now' nutritionist talks SNAP, food policy and the 'triple duty' diet
item.description: Marion Nestle says we need to rethink how we eat. She recommends "real food, processed as little as possible, with a big emphasis on plants." Her new book is What to Eat Now.
item.content:encoded:
Marion Nestle says we need to rethink how we eat. She recommends "real food, processed as little as possible, with a big emphasis on plants." Her new book is What to Eat Now.

(Image credit: Allison Dinner)
item.dc:creator: Tonya Mosley

item.title: The Supreme Court will hear a challenge to grace periods for mail ballot returns
item.description: The Supreme Court will hear a case that could decide whether states can count postmarked mail ballots that arrive after Election Day — something that about 20 states and territories currently allow.
item.content:encoded:
The Supreme Court will hear a case that could decide whether states can count postmarked mail ballots that arrive after Election Day — something that about 20 states and territories currently allow.

(Image credit: Lindsey Wasson)
item.dc:creator: Ashley Lopez

item.title: COVID vaccine rollout and pandemic preparedness assessed in new book, 'Fair Doses'
item.description: In his new book, 'Fair Doses,' epidemiologist Seth Berkley discusses what went right -- and wrong -- with COVID vaccine distribution and whether the world is ready if a new pandemic were to strike.
item.content:encoded:
In his new book, 'Fair Doses,' epidemiologist Seth Berkley discusses what went right -- and wrong -- with COVID vaccine distribution and whether the world is ready if a new pandemic were to strike.

(Image credit: Ben de la Cruz/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: 'Nuremberg' is full of big questions — and missed opportunities
item.description: The new film portrays Hitler's second-in-command, Hermann Goering, as a wily mastermind, sidestepping uncomfortable questions about how unexceptional evil can be.
item.content:encoded:
Nuremberg is in theaters now.'/>

The new film portrays Hitler's second-in-command, Hermann Goering, as a wily mastermind, sidestepping uncomfortable questions about how unexceptional evil can be.

(Image credit: Scott Garfield)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Jonah Wolpert

item.title: Senate approves legislation to end shutdown. And, where climate change efforts stand
item.description: The House returns to vote on a bipartisan bill that could end the government shutdown. And, at the COP30, data show the world is still far from meeting its climate goals.
item.content:encoded:
The House returns to vote on a bipartisan bill that could end the government shutdown. And, at the COP30, data show the world is still far from meeting its climate goals.

(Image credit: Anna Rose Layden)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton
